pv3199.lib.java.math.structures

Class Matrix<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • pv3199.lib.java.math.structures.Matrix<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the data this matrix structure holds.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    NumberMatrix

    public abstract class Matrix<T>
extends Object
implements Serializable
    A matrix structure intended to hold elements in a rectangular 2D array.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

              int height,
              boolean allowsNull)
       throws IllegalArgumentException

        height - the height of the matrix.
        allowsNull - if this matrix will accept null values or not.

        IllegalArgumentException - if the dimensions are negative.

      • Matrix

        public Matrix(T[][] initialData,
              boolean allowsNull)
       throws NullPointerException,
              IllegalArgumentException
        Constructs a Matrix with a boolean indicating whether it will accept null values or not and initial data to store into this matrix.
        Parameters:
        initialData - the initial data for this matrix to hold.
        allowsNull - if this matrix will accept null values or not.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the initial data is null
        IllegalArgumentException - if the initial data array is not rectangular or if the initial data contains null values and this matrix is not intended to accept null values.

      • forEach

        public final void forEach(ConsumerHolder<T> action)
        Iterates through each element in the matrix. Instead of using a Consumer that accepts the generic type of this matrix, the consumer accepts a ForEachHolder that has the same generic type of this matrix. The ForEachHolder allows for the consumer implementation to access what indices the matrix is currently iterating at. The iteration goes from rows to columns (top to bottom, left to right), similar to a 2D-array. As such, the ForEachHolder's indices will have the row index in the first element, column index in the second element, and the matrix element as it's data. If the implementation does not need to access the indices of each iteration, then it is advised to utilize forEach(Consumer) for efficiency.
        Parameters:
        action - - the consumer to utilize when iterating through each element.
        See Also:
        ForEachHolder, Consumer, ConsumerHolder

      • forEach

        public final void forEach(Consumer<T> action)
        Iterates through each element in the matrix, performing a consumer operation on each. Iteration goes from rows to columns (top to bottom, left to right), similar to a 2D-array. This is a more efficient alternative to forEach(ConsumerHolder).
        Parameters:
        action - the consumer to utilize when iterating through each element.

      • forEachRow

        public final void forEachRow(ConsumerHolder<T[]> action,
                             Class<T> clazz)
        Iterates through each row in the matrix. Instead of using a Consumer that accepts the generic type of this matrix, the consumer accepts a ForEachHolder that has the same generic type of this matrix. The ForEachHolder allows for the consumer implementation to access the row-index the matrix is currently iterating at. The iteration goes from top to bottom. As such the ForEachHolder's indices will have the row index in the first element, and will contain a T array, representing the current row, as it's data. If the implementation does not need to access the indices of each iteration, then it is advised to utilize forEach(Consumer) for efficiency.
        Parameters:
        action - - the consumer to utilize when iterating through each row.
        clazz - - the type the matrix holds.
        See Also:
        ForEachHolder, Consumer, ConsumerHolder

      • forEachRow

        public final void forEachRow(Consumer<T[]> action,
                             Class<T> clazz)
        Iterates through each row in the matrix, performing a consumer operation on each. Iteration goes from top to bottom. This is a more efficient alternative to forEachRow(ConsumerHolder, Class).
        Parameters:
        action - the consumer to utilize when iterating through each row.
        clazz - the type the matrix holds.

      • forEachColumn

        public final void forEachColumn(ConsumerHolder<T[]> action,
                                Class<T> clazz)
        Iterates through each column in the matrix. Instead of using a Consumer that accepts the generic type of this matrix, the consumer accepts a ForEachHolder that has the same generic type of this matrix. The ForEachHolder allows for the consumer implementation to access the column-index the matrix is currently iterating at. The iteration goes from left to right. As such the ForEachHolder's indices will have the column index in the first element, and will contain a T array, representing the current column, as it's data. If the implementation does not need to access the indices of each iteration, then it is advised to utilize forEach(Consumer) for efficiency.
        Parameters:
        action - - the consumer to utilize when iterating through each column.
        clazz - - the type the matrix holds.
        See Also:
        ForEachHolder, Consumer, ConsumerHolder

      • forEachColumn

        public final void forEachColumn(Consumer<T[]> action,
                                Class<T> clazz)
        Iterates through each column in the matrix, performing a consumer operation on each. Iteration goes from left to right. This is a more efficient alternative to forEachColumn(ConsumerHolder, Class).
        Parameters:
        action - the consumer to utilize when iterating through each column.
        clazz - the type the matrix holds.
